results.title: The Classroom
results.creator_credit: Patrick Ryan, Eltham Films and Tim Burstall
results.brief_description: Puppet film for children. Sebastian the Fox appears in a typical classroom with children playing pranks on their master as well as on each other. As so often happens the innocent are punished, in this case Sebastian. The offenders are eventually caught and receive their just desserts.

results.title: The Classic guitar: a miniature orchestra
results.creator_credit: Nina Collier, Lee R. Bobker, Arts and Audiences and Dynamic Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Music for Young People”.
Discusses and demonstrates the use of the versatility of the guitar and explains how colour and other effects are produced. Features Rey de la Torre.

results.title: The Class of '01: the college of tomorrow
results.creator_credit: Isaac Kleinerman, Peter Poor and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
A glimpse of what the universities of the future (2001) will be like. Examines new multi-media methods such as computerised control centres and closed circuit TV. Community colleges and the possible “bottling in film” of great professors are explained. Advanced methods of teacher training and new educational technologies are shown, and the question of what will happen to the creative processes in tomorrow’s classrooms is explored. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Class
results.creator_credit: Huw Wheldon, John Schlesinger and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Monitor”.
A close-up of the work of a class in a drama school and of the methods used to train the aspiring actors and actresses. John Schlesinger’s command of the particular directing technique required is such that the film appears to have been made spontaneously during the forty minutes or so of the single class. In fact it needed a week’s shooting and a considerable amount of preparation in order to give this impression. The tutor (Harold Lang) uses the Mercy Speech from ‘The Merchant of Venice’ as a starting point in an improvisation by the students. Originally made for the BBC Television program ‘Monitor’, it is exciting to watch a production in the hands of a dedicated artist.

results.title: The Claim
results.brief_description: About some of the processes of industrial negotiations. The progress of a log of claims is followed from its inception in the work place through its many stages of direct negotiations with the employer or through the process of conciliation and arbitration.

results.title: The City with a future
results.creator_credit: Robert Dierbeck and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Examines two aspects of environmental city planning. Although Disney-World, Florida, is not a real city, the Disney planners have come up with some surprising technological solutions to urban problems. The film also shows how the citizens of Toronto have shown that it is possible to change the pattern of urban growth and make a city liveable again.

results.title: The city that waits to die
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: An alert from scientists concerned with a catastrophic fate for San Francisco based on earthquake conditions presented by the San Andreas fault. Includes scenes of earthquakes and describes some of the radical experiments being conducted in starting and stopping earthquakes.

results.title: The City of the future
results.creator_credit: Art Ciocco, Edmund Bacon and Urban Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Understanding Cities”.
A documentary that looks at the future design and development of the cities in the world. Factors that will influence these future designs include the limited amounts of energy and resources that are left in the world. Narrated by Edmund Bacon.

results.title: The City of Chromatic Dissolution
results.brief_description: In three-colour separation studies of the CBD of Melbourne shot in 1986 on very outdated rolls of Ilford Pan F black-and-white negative, evidence of chemical dissolution appears as cyan, magenta and yellow spots on the colour prints.

constellations_other.name: Communicating colour
constellations_other.description: An exploration of colour on-screen inspired by Technicolor supervisor, Natalie Kalmus.

results.description: In three-colour separation studies of the CBD of Melbourne shot in 1986 on very outdated rolls of Ilford Pan F black and white negative, evidence of chemical dissolution appears as cyan, magenta and yellow spots on the colour prints. The other ‘dissolution’ - the 3-colour separation and reconstitution of the colour of the image - shows in the pedestrian and motor traffic activity, and also in the mirror-facaded ‘invisible’ office buildings in St Kilda Road. The film is accompanied by layers of city sounds and electronically altered bowed glass effects.
description_for_label: In three-colour separation studies of the CBD of Melbourne shot in 1986 on very outdated rolls of Ilford Pan F black and white negative, evidence of chemical dissolution appears as cyan, magenta and yellow spots on the colour prints. The other ‘dissolution’ - the 3-colour separation and reconstitution of the colour of the image - shows in the pedestrian and motor traffic activity, and also in the mirror-facaded ‘invisible’ office buildings in St Kilda Road. The film is accompanied by layers of city sounds and electronically altered bowed glass effects.
